Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: School Segregation and Resegregation: Using Case Studies and Public Polls to Understand Citizen Attitudes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Why are some school districts able to sustain school desegregation while others are not? Although social scientists have been active in studying the effects of school racial composition on student achievement, relatively neglected is the inclusion of variation among districts in the social factors that lead to school district segregation itself. Using five case studies and public opinion polls, the research team will study the relationship between citizen characteristics and their attitudes and values supporting (or failing to support) school desegregation. This study increases the value of five strategically chosen case studies including those of Wake County, NC (Raleigh); Davidson County, TN (Nashville); Jefferson County, KY (Louisville); Charlotte-Mecklenburg, NC and Rock Hill, SC by fielding an opinion poll in each location, where the polls contain mostly common questions across sites. These polls will reveal similarities and differences in adult attitudes that track to differences in how long these districts have sustained desegregated schools. Study findings have implications for other school districts beyond the five studied here in terms of formulating policy that will better support socioeconomic mixing of students, which enhances diversity by promoting educational attainment and upward mobility in society, especially for at-risk students.

Some school districts sustain desegregation over many years while others do not. Existing research is largely based on case studies. Case studies have limited external validity and are often heterogeneous in approach because researchers frame questions and invoke theory differently. The data obtained from in-depth interviews, participant observation, and document analyses are rarely triangulated with data from theoretically-driven surveys of the school district's adult population. These attitudes and values play an important part in explaining districts' current school assignment policies and inform future policies as well. This study addresses gaps in existing social science literature on desegregation by using a common theoretical perspective and fielding a largely common questionnaire via Interactive Voice Response, supplemented by cell phone samples, across five school districts. The research will produce poll data on a minimum of 5000 adult respondents. Analysis will (1) embed each poll within the existing qualitative data on each case; and (2) use the poll data to analyze both commonalities and differences in values and attitudes across sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two questions motivate this project: Why have some formerly desegregated school systems remained diverse while others have resegregated? What is the relationship, if any, between local public opinion about diversity and a school district's education policy?  The purpose of our project is to study adult attitudes towards school desegregation and resegregation in five southern locales: Raleigh, NC; Charlotte, NC; Rock Hill, SC: Louisville, KY, and Nashville, TN. This collaborative grant,  comprised of three linked awards to Roslyn Arlin Mickelson, Toby L. Parcel, and Stephen Samuel Smith, is an interdisciplinary study based in sociology and political science.   We collected public opinion data on desegregation, school diversity, and educational reform from roughly 1000 adults in each of the five sites (N=5302) using a combination of live cell phone and interactive voice response interviews. We then employed a procedure known as post-stratification weighting, also known as raking ratio estimation (raking), or sample balancing to address sample self-selection and to enhance external validity of our findings.  By triangulating these 2015 opinion poll data with extant qualitative case studies from each of the five school systems, we are able to better understand why three of the districts have remained desegregated while two have resegregated, and we are beginning to understand local education policy responsiveness from a comparative perspective. Our findings that especially address the project's intellectual merit and begin to answer its motivating questions are:


1--We analyzed local policy responsiveness in a comparative framework by examining the relationship between local public opinion about educational diversity and levels of desegregation in our five sites: Charlotte, NC; Louisville, KY; Nashville, TN; Raleigh, NC; and Rock Hill, SC. Drawing on our public opinion data in each school system, we ranked (high to low) the five districts by respondents' opinions in support for diversity. Across all sites, we find considerable correspondence between levels of support for diversity and levels of desegregation. This correspondence does not improve when we control for respondents' income. But it does improve when we control for race; i.e., there is an almost perfect correspondence between the rankings of levels of desegregation and the rankings of white support for diversity, while there is little to no relationship between rankings of levels of school desegregation and support for it among blacks.


2--We found that support for magnet schools is widespread across race, sex, social class, and political groupings, but that support for charter schools is more likely among Republicans and those who favor conservative ideologies.  Parents of school aged children and other adults hold similar attitudes towards charters and magnets.  Respondents who have heightened concerns about the challenges of public school reassignments, the dangers to children from being reassigned to different schools, and the uncertainty that such reassignments bring are more likely to favor both magnet and charter schools. Those who see public schools as beneficial to all community children are likely to favor magnets.


3--The major findings from Parcel and Taylor's 2015 book, The End of Consensus: Diversity, Neighborhoods, and the Politics of Public School Assignments, have been replicated with the 2015 survey data, and many of the findings they reported are replicated across the four additional southern school districts.  Illustrative findings include the similarity of attitudes structure across sites and across time.  Specifically, key attitudinal dimensions include support for diverse schools, for neighborhood schools, and concerns regarding the challenges, dangers and uncertainties associated with childrens' involuntary reassignments when they attend public schools.  Our replications of Parcel and Taylor's initial study both in Raleigh and the four other sites contribute to social science's growing emphasis on the conditions that facilitate or impede successful replication, and to NSF's Robust and Reliable initiative.


The project outcomes are consistent with the proposed broader impact of the study. The project provided an Undergraduate Research Experience for six students two of whom are white, two of whom are African American, two of whom are Latinx; and five of whom are women. The study's results have implications for social policy issues related specifically to conditions that foster school diversity, and more broadly to the sociology of education, political sociology, stratification, and racial inequality.
